By MARVIN HUNDERTMARK
In the face of increasing
campus automobile registration,
Joseph Geiger, assistant plant
manager, stated that no new
parking lots can be constructed
"without destroying the integrity
of the university campus."
In the search for a future
remedy to this situation Geiger
further stated that the parking
commission, of which he is a
member, and the university administration are presently studying the feasibility of installing

7678 Autos Registered
Every week Hopkins' 815 parking spaces 'including 82 at the
faculty club) serve an automobile
registration of 7,678. A total of
5,174 student and 214 facultyowned vehicles scramble for
spaces before the evening classes
at McCoy College. During the
daylight hours 1,317 students, 520
faculty members and 453 employees park their cars on
campus.
By groups, 523 spaces are allotted to day students and visi-

tors, 190 to day faculty members, persons with faculty status
and employees, and 102 to day
faculty members alone. During
McCoy College hours when many
of the day faculty and employee
parking spaces are not needed'
and can be distributed among
the students, 652 spaces are
available to the student registration and 163 to faculty drivers.,
McCoy Troubles Greatest
Consequently, McCoy College
students and faculty members
have the bigger campus parking
problem. Nevertheless, checks of
the parking lots during the day
and complaints by students and
faculty members indicate that
the lots are filled to capacity
during most of the day and cannot accommodate all automobiles coming on campus during
certain hours, particularly early
in the morning.
To make matters worse, campus automobile registration is increasing at an average rate of
10% a year. Last year, for instance, only 7,218 cars were registered at the university.
Studies conducted by an engineering firm and by the university administration indicate

that no other large area can be
used as a parking lot without
detracting "greatly" from the
"integrity" of the campus. Formerly, the area west of the botanical gardens was considered and
turned down because roadways
leading to the lot from the rest
of the campus would be congested
and entrances from Wyman Park
Drive would encourage illegal
parking by non-university members.
Car Pools
In an effort to forestall measures as drastic as the installation
of parking meters, Geiger recently polled faculty members and
employees concerning their attitude toward the establishment
of a car pool. The results of the
survey have not yet been released. Jim Michaels, the newly
appointed Student Council representative to the parking commission, will conduct a similar
survey in the near future to
gauge student attitude and the
feasibility of establishing a car
pool among the day school students.

Violations Reduced
One bright spot in the parking
situation is that the flagrant
parking regulation violator has
all but disappeared from the
campus. Tighter parking regulations, towing away of illegally
parked cars, and fair, impartial
enforcement have apparently
discouraged the ticket collector.
Appeals of parking tickets are
acted upon by the parking commission consisting of one student Council member, one McCoy College faculty member, one
representative,
administration
one day school faculty member,
Plant Manager Wesley A. Taylor,
and Joseph Geiger. Last year 111
appeals were granted, 85 denied
and 23 waived and assessed.

distributing companies install
meters gratis in exchange for a
certain percentage of the income from them. Meters would
probably discourage fraternity
members and other students living nearby from parking on

believe the students should give

Almost every other large college or university in the country has a major parking problem. Many have solved the
problem in unique ways. Michigan State, for instance, used
the revenue from park in g

meters to build a multi-level
garage. Other institutions limit
driving on campus to seniors or
to juniors and seniors.
A few schools limit driving

from the campus. None of these
plans have been rejected outby

Of Responsibility
Tony Salem, Student Council
president, told the members of
the Council recently that "our
job is to represent the students,"
and that "only one unexcused
absence is allowed 'for the coming school year)—after that, a
member is subject to being
dropped from the Council."
He also stated, last week, that
the Council has jurisdiction over
the Inter-Fraternity Board and
that the Council can make recommendations concerning student drinking.
"The Stuctent Council should
issue a statement (concerning
student behavior outside classrooms) but it is not up to us to
enforce rules in the Dorms, for
example. The Gentleman's Code
doesn't set up specific rules
governing student behavior, but
the Council should set up such
rules.
"By bringing a student (suspected of ungentlemanly behavior) before the Council, I think'
we will be able to control (ungentlemanly behavior). If a
student causes destruction, we
will charge him for it, but he'll
have to admit it first . . . I
don't, however, want to start a
trial system," Salem stated.

Head Parents'Day Events
"Good attendance" is anticipated for tomorrow's
Parents' Day events by chairman Howie Richter. "We
expect at least 175 parents, and plans are ready for a
very pleasant day," be said.
Sponsored by the YMCA, Omicron Delta Kappa, the
Booster Club, and the Dormitory Students' Representative
Council, the day will begin at 10:15 a.m. with campus
tours leaving from the front of
Levering Hall.
The DSRC will sponsor a
luncheon and reception in the
dorm Snack Bar at 12:30 p.m.
The parents are then invited to
attend the Hopkins-Army Lacrosse game at Homewood Field.
A "special" banquet at 6:15
in Levering Hall Cafeteria will
highlight the day's activities.
Robert Bridgers, line coach for
the Baltimore Colts and recent
Hopkins football mentor, will be
the principal speaker. The Barnstormers' production of "The
Time of Your Life" is expected
to draw a good attendance of
the day's guests at 8:30 in
Shriver Hall.
Parents' Day was first held last
Year and was "quite successful,"
according to Dr. Chester L. Wickwire, YMCA Executive Secretary.
The Purpose of Parents' Day,
said Richter, is "to serve a dual
Purpose of affording the parents
an insight into activities on the
Hopkins campus and fostering a
community spirit among parents,
students, and faculty."
Parents of all dormitory students and YMCA members have
been invited. Recently the IFB
has also discussed sponsoring a
fraternity Parents' Day in conjunction with next year's affair.
This would afford parents of
fraternity members the chance
to attend as well and would obviate crowded conditions inherent in the present system, by
Which each fraternity holds its
own weekend. Final decision is
expected soon.

The William W.Bain Memorial
Cup, established by this year's
senior class in memoriam to deceased Hulaballoo editor Bill
Bain, will be awarded to the "outstanding undergraduates in journalism" at this week's ArmyHopkins lacrosse game.
The Cup will then be awarded
annually each successive year,
the recipient being chosen by a
permanent five-man board representing the News-Letter, Hulaballoo, Vector, Handbook, and
Jayword. Any undergraduate in
any aspect of journalism, photography or business on campus
publications, is eligible. The Cup
will not be awarded to the same
person twice.
The half-time of any home lacrosse game will mark the time
of presentation, the recipient's
name remaining unknown until
then.
"Bill was an outstanding member of this community and was
best known for his photography,
especially in the Hulaballoo,"
said Bob Mitgang, member of
the senior class committee which
established the award, and which
is headed by Clarke Tankersley.

No Ideal Education

might constitute an ideal educational system, Dr. Boas said,
"After teaching since 1915, I
have realized one fact: men can
be pretty well educated under
any kind of system." He said
that he favored the old elective
system initiated by President
Elliot of Harvard, wherein a stu-

dent could select his entire curriculum. "I don't think the student under this system got a
'well-rounded' education ... No
ideal can ever be recognized. I
think we've got to wake up to
the fact that the fields of knowledge are now so varied and that
so much preliminary knowledge
is required in them, that we
can't expect a person to be a
scholar in all of them." The
only way to get a true education, he said, would be "to do a
lot of random reading, not reading which is directed by someone
else ... The best way to get a
broad education is to specialize,
as paradoxical as it may seem.
When you begin to specialize,
you begin to see you've got to
know a lot of things outside of
your field, in order to understand your subject. When you
realize this, the drive to learn
comes from within you.
"For example, when a man
realizes that he's got to learn
German in order to understand
his subject, then he will learn it.
But when someone says a man
has to learn German, there is
always a resentment and resistance. That's just simple psychology."

George Boas To Retire
Views Ideal Education
Dr. George Boas, professor of
the History of Philosophy, has
announced that he will definitely
retire at the end of this semester, thus terminating a forty-two
year career of active teaching.
The last thirty-six years of his
were spent at the
career
Hopkins.
Dr. Boas, however, will not
terminate his academic researches. He has a Guggenheim
fellowship for next year, and
plans to use it while studying
abroad. He will concurrently be
working on a book "dealing with
what Aristotle took for granted."
He is also finishing up a book
co-authored with Harold Holmes
Wren, entitled "What Is a Picture?" This book, based on Dr.
Boas' recent article in the Johns
Hopkins Magazine, will contain
approximately 200 illustvations,
and, he said, "will be written in
the simplest possible terms." 1-n
the meanwhile, Dr. Boas is
awaiting the publication of his
contribution to the Carus Lectures, which will be published in
a volume called "The Inquiring
Mind." (The Carus Lectures are
given in Chicago. Johns Hopkins
is the only University ever to
have sent two speakers to these
lectures: Dr. Arthur Oncken
Lovejoy, professor emeritus of
philosophy, preceded Dr. Boas.)
No Ideal Education
In a consideration of what
might constitute an ideal educational system, Dr. Boas said,
"After teaching since 1915, I
have realized one fact: men can
be pretty well educated under
any kind of system." He said
that he favored the old elective
system initiated by President
Elliot of Harvard, wherein a stu-

dent could select his entire curriculum. "I don't think the student under this system got a
'well-rounded' education ... No
ideal can ever be recognized. I
think we've got to wake up to
the fact that the fields of knowledge are now so varied and that
so much preliminary knowledge
is required in them, that we
can't expect a person to be a
scholar in all of them." The
only way to get a true education, he said, would be "to do a
lot of random reading, not reading which is directed by someone
else ... The best way to get a
broad education is to specialize,
as paradoxical as it may seem.
When you begin to specialize,
you begin to see you've got to
know a lot of things outside of
your field, in order to understand your subject. When you
realize this, the drive to learn
comes from within you.
"For example, when a man
realizes that he's got to learn
German in order to understand
his subject, then he will learn it.
But when someone says a man
has to learn German, there is
always a resentment and resistance. That's just simple psychology."
Specialization At JHU
When he was asked if Hopkins
at present would tend to promote the cultivation of this type
of early investigation through
specialization, Dr. Boas replied,
"I don't think so. There is not
much in the way of an elective
system here now. There seems
to be an increasing tendency
toward the establishment of particular requirements. I think
this is a great misfortune."
Dr. Boas said that he did not

believe that the Hopkins undergraduate, on the whole, was capable of taking advantage of a
system wherein a great deal of
personally directed study and
research would be a key factor.
"This needs to be qualified," he
said. "When I was Chairman of
the Group Council, most of the
biology majors (I imagine most
of -those were pre-medical students) seemed to be better than
the others. There is an uneven
distribution in the undergraduate school. Usur"y the students
who come here for particular
things, such as the history of
the social. sciences are among
the better students.
"In the graduate school, circumstances are different. In the
Philosophy department, this year
the graduate students are the
best crop _we've .ever had. This
is, indeed, the only reason I regret leaving."
Advising Essential
He emphasized that under a
system allowing a free choice of
studies, a strong advisor system
was essential on the undergraduate level. "The student entering
the University needs some advice. He doesn't know what the
various courses are, and an advisor can-do a great deal in helping him ... Another role of the
advisor should be to get to know
his students' possibilities, their
aptitudes, and their general interests in life. If the advisor
were able, and the student willing, a real understanding (I was
going to say friendship) could
be set up between the two. The
relationship would then not just
be a perfunctory thing. Of
course, there's no sense in trying to bring about that sort of
